content.title: Compression Therapy
content.definition: Therapeutic application of external pressure to the lower extremity using bandages, stockings, or devices to reduce venous hypertension, improve venous return, reduce edema, and promote healing of venous ulcers. Cornerstone of chronic venous disease management.

key_concepts.description: External compression reduces venous diameter → improves valve coaptation → reduces reflux → lowers ambulatory venous pressure → reduces edema and capillary leak → improves tissue oxygenation
Graduated compression: highest at ankle, decreasing proximally; typically 20-40 mmHg at ankle; mimics physiologic pressure distribution
Class 1 (15-20 mmHg): mild edema, prevention. Class 2 (20-30 mmHg): moderate CVI, post-ablation. Class 3 (30-40 mmHg): severe CVI, ulcers. Class 4 (40-50+ mmHg): lymphedema, severe edema
Stockings (elastic), bandages (short-stretch preferred for ulcers), multilayer systems (Profore, Unna boot), pneumatic compression devices, Velcro wraps
Short-stretch (inelastic): high working pressure during ambulation, low resting pressure; better for ulcers. Long-stretch (elastic): sustained pressure at rest; stockings are long-stretch
Zinc oxide-impregnated gauze wrap; provides semi-rigid compression; short-stretch behavior; changed weekly; traditional for venous ulcers but less convenient than multilayer
Severe peripheral arterial disease (ABI <0.5); uncompensated heart failure; severe peripheral neuropathy; skin conditions over application area; infected ulcer without proper treatment
Essential before compression: ABI >0.8 = full compression; 0.5-0.8 = modified/reduced compression (20-30 mmHg); <0.5 = contraindicated
Compression increases ulcer healing rate by ~50% compared to no compression; multi-layer bandaging may be more effective than single layer; 4-layer systems standard for ulcers
Lifelong compression stockings (Class 2-3) reduce venous ulcer recurrence from 70% to 30%; critical for long-term management
Patient adherence challenging due to difficulty donning, discomfort, aesthetics; donning aids available; Velcro wraps easier for elderly/limited dexterity; education critical

learning_objectives: Understand the mechanism of compression in venous disease
Select appropriate compression class for clinical scenario
Recognize the importance of lifelong compression for recurrence prevention
clinical_pearls: Always check ABI before compression - contraindicated if <0.5
Compression reduces ulcer healing time by 50%
Class 3 (30-40 mmHg) for active venous ulcers
Patient adherence is the biggest challenge - address early
common_mistakes: Not recommending lifelong maintenance after ulcer healing
Using long-stretch stockings for active ulcers (short-stretch better)
Ignoring patient difficulty with donning (offer alternatives)
